awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Plasma-Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PE-CVD) Diamond Growth for Photonic Switches
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is significant, as it addresses the critical need for high-purity diamond substrates in various ongoing science programs. Several of these programs have been hindered by lack of Diamond substrates which are repeatable and reproducible as well as being commonly available. project’s advancement will not only propel scientific research but also has the potential to revolutionize industries by improving the performance and capabilities of devices such as photonic switches. Large 10 mm size diamond substrates will be produced, a size which is currently not available. The research focus is upon the societal benefits include advancements in technology that contribute to national security and healthcare, particularly in areas such as radiation therapy dosimetry. The commercial impact is promising, with the potential to establish the United States as a leader in semiconductor diamond production which has been and setting up a large-scale PE-CVD (Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition) diamond platform for limited lab production.  Diamond devices, when manufactured can lead by creating technology and economic growth to commercialization across a range of fields spanning:  semiconductors and advanced electronics, optical lenses/Raman laser, high voltage switches, and radiation monitoring devices.  

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to address the challenge of limited availability of high-quality diamond substrates, which hinders progress in various ongoing commercial and science programs. The research objectives include establishing a nitrogen matrix study to control and maintain consistency in nitrogen levels, which has been a significant barrier in the past. The project will grow and fabricate diamond substrates with the required purity and dopant levels, tailored for specific applications. The research will utilize Plasma-Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PE-CVD) to grow diamond films and create Standard Reference Materials (SRMs) for potential standardization. Anticipated technical results encompass providing nitrogen matrix slices for evaluation, establishing nitrogen selection for a Photonic High-Frequency (HF) microwave switch. This project is strengthening the only domestic supply chain that has been established since 2020 for semiconductor Diamond Substrates.  The project aims to significantly advance the field by delivering semiconductor diamond devices that outperform current offerings in High frequency Microwave switching and proton irradiation therapy dosimetry as well as other applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Phase 1 NSF Final Report Summary

Objective and Goals

The Phase 1 NSF study aimed to develop semiconductor diamond substrates adhering to industry standards, enhancing commercialization prospects for diamond wafers and devices. The research explored diamond-based applications, including proton irradiation dosimetry. Over four months, multiple CVD diamond growth runs were completed to increase substrate size and availability.

The study also investigated various nitrogen doping levels to explore potential applications in high-frequency switching. Findings from Phase 1 will inform further research in Phase 2.

The research focused on addressing the global shortage of high-quality, scalable diamond materials for semiconductor applications.

Nitrogen Matrix Study

Demand for diamond in semiconductor applications continues to grow, prompting efforts to improve large-scale production capabilities. Developing ultra-wide bandgap (UWBG) materials is a priority for advancing semiconductor technologies.

The study examined nitrogen doping levels and their impact on electrical properties and material transparency. Further refinement of doping processes is planned for Phase 2.

Experimental Steps and Findings

The study executed multiple nitrogen doping matrix runs using diamond seed slices. A dozen growth runs were performed with different nitrogen doping levels.

Key findings:

  • A technique was developed to control dopant gas incorporation.
  • Multiple polished slices were processed and analyzed for nitrogen concentration.
  • Advancements in slicing techniques reduced material loss and improved precision.
  • High nitrogen doping levels affected light transmission, requiring adjustments in Phase 2.

Advantages of Diamond Technology

Diamond technology offers several advantages:

  • Stress-free growth processes enable controlled crystal facet formation.
  • Compatibility with semiconductor materials supports large-scale applications.
  • Optical and chemical bonding capabilities facilitate integration with various semiconductors.
  • High-voltage applications benefit from diamond’s electrical properties.
  • Stability in harsh environments makes diamond suitable for radiation sensors and semiconductor devices.

Challenges and Next Steps for Phase 2

Challenges identified in Phase 1 include:

  • High nitrogen doping levels affected optical properties, requiring concentration adjustments.
  • Some samples displayed void defects at extreme nitrogen levels.
  • Reactor limitations restricted certain doping studies, which will be addressed in Phase 2.

Phase 2 will focus on:

  • Developing optimized dosimetry substrates for radiation applications.
  • Refining nitrogen doping levels for improved performance.
  • Scaling up production techniques.

Future Applications and Market Strategy

Potential applications of this technology include:

  • Quantum computing and sensing.
  • High-power electronics for power grids and AI chips.
  • High-voltage switching devices.
  • Laser optics with enhanced durability.
  • Radiation monitoring devices.

Efforts to establish semiconductor-grade diamond standards and commercialization pathways are ongoing.

Key Takeaways

  • The study successfully executed multiple nitrogen doping runs.
  • Diamond’s unique properties make it a strong candidate for next-generation semiconductor applications. Ultra-Wide Bandgap Semiconductor
  • Phase 2 will refine processes and expand research into dosimetry applications.
  • Ongoing National Labs collaborations aim to drive commercial adoption of semiconductor-grade diamond materials and devices.
